image.altText: A man wearing a suit stands behind media microphones and in front of a banner with SA Police logo

items.synopsis: SA Police suspect two elderly people, who died one year apart, may have been murdered by the same person after abnormalities in both of their toxicology reports were found.

title.children: Police open murder investigation into deaths of couple who died one year apart

image.altText: A crowd, some standing, some sitting, some waving Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags behind a gate

items.synopsis: South Australia has delayed the introduction of its state-based Voice to Parliament, just months from the referendum to decide whether to create a national Voice.

title.children: South Australia delays Voice to Parliament elections over 'confusion' with national vote

image.altText: Martin Duku walking outside a court building wearing a suit and glasses

items.synopsis: A former South Australian police officer who indecently assaulted two women in Port Augusta has been sentenced to 15 months' prison, despite concerns from his lawyer it would not be safe for him.

title.children: Former cop jailed for indecent assault despite safety concerns

image.altText: Steps leading down to a beach with a small patch of sand and ocean

items.synopsis: Coastal erosion is washing sand away from some of Adelaide's most popular beaches at a rapid pace, with a state government review still months away from completion.

title.children: No turning of the tide in battle to protect Adelaide's beaches from coastal erosion

image.altText: Close-up of man

items.synopsis: Victoria Cross recipient Ben Roberts-Smith lost one of the most expensive legal cases in Australian history this month. Now he has agreed to pay the legal costs incurred by the defendants.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith agrees to pay defamation case legal costs, which could run into tens of millions

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian and Daryl Maguire

items.synopsis: The New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption hands down its findings into former NSW premier Gladys Berejiklian and former Liberal MP, Daryl Maguire. Catch up with all the key moments.

title.children: Former NSW premier and ex-partner engaged in corrupt conduct - as it happened

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian close up

items.synopsis: The former NSW premier thanks her supporters and says the ICAC report is with her legal team.

title.children: Berejiklian releases statement after ICAC finds she took part in corrupt conduct

image.altText: A puppy is held by a worker.

items.synopsis: Big brands such as Woolworths, the RSPCA and Pet Barn have been temporarily blocked from selling pet insurance.

title.children: Big brands blocked from selling pet insurance

image.altText: Debris from the Titan submersible recovered from the ocean floor.

items.synopsis: "Presumed" human remains are recovered from within the shattered hulk of a submersible that imploded while on a voyage to the century-old wreck of the Titanic earlier this month.

title.children: 'Presumed' human remains recovered inside debris from imploded Titan submersible as parts returned to shore

image.altText: Richard Marles with short grey hair wearing grey suit holds a plaque with Manasseh Sogavare in a black suit

items.synopsis: Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles says Australia is willing to continue providing troops and police support to Solomon Islands.

title.children: Marles commits to ongoing defence, security support for Solomon Islands

image.altText: A group of PNG women and babies sitting on a verandah

items.synopsis: A group of bandits that kidnapped an Australian professor in the PNG Highlands appears to have struck again, this time snatching and assaulting a group of women and girls. Warning: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: The PNG gang that kidnapped an Australian professor may now be unleashing new horrors on teen girls

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: The treasurer will soon announce the fate of the RBA governor and economists are split over whether Philip Lowe should stay until rates settle or make way for new blood to guide the bank through turbulent economic times ahead.

title.children: Many economists say Philip Lowe made a 'huge error'. So will he keep his job?

image.altText: Danny and Michael sitting down looking down at a screen

items.synopsis: With youthful energy and a quintessentially Australian soundtrack, the debut film from the RackaRacka brothers hits all the right notes.

title.children: Australian 'in a way that doesn't feel gross': Lifelong dream comes true for Adelaide filmmakers

image.altText: Close up of dog behind fence with a shelter in the background.

items.synopsis: A regional animal rescue needs to find an extra $60,000 in donations after one of its funding agreements came to an end.

title.children: This shelter says it will keep rescuing animals despite losing funding. But they can't do it alone

image.altText: A woman with short hair and glasses putting up a closed sign in a door window

items.synopsis: Ange Lawrie opened her cafe in South Australia's south-east just before interest rates started rising. It is closing this week after falling sales — a situation facing eateries around Australia as winter bites.

title.children: Hospitality businesses hit hard as interest rates rise while temperatures plummet

image.altText: Two Russian military men in army gear gesturing,

items.synopsis: A New York Times report, based on a US intelligence briefing, said General Sergei Surovikin had advance knowledge of the mutiny and that Russian authorities were checking if he was complicit.

title.children: Rumours swirl about fate of Russia's top generals who have not been seen in public since aborted mercenary mutiny

image.altText: A woman smiling, looking into the camera

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court jury has been told Hunter woman Danielle Easey was killed after making threats against people in the local drug scene.

title.children: Danielle Easey was allegedly murdered after 'the crack ran out and she lost it', jury told

image.altText: Giles sits cross-legged on the floor of his apartment. He uses one hand to push his head towards his shoulder.

items.synopsis: Australian researchers call for an end to the use of opioids to treat acute back and neck pain after finding they are no more effective than a placebo.

title.children: Giles was prescribed opioids for his back pain. A new study suggests the drugs were pointless

image.altText: Two teenage girls with long, dark, braided hair. Their backs are to the lens.

items.synopsis: Melinda Scash took a leave of absence when an independent workplace review into Highview College was launched earlier this month. She has stepped down ahead of the findings being delivered.

title.children: Victorian principal accused of unfair treatment over students' braided hair resigns

image.altText: Illustration of black holes and gravitational waves

items.synopsis: Astronomers around the world have found the first hints of elusive fingerprint of gravitational waves created by monster black holes at the centre of galaxies.

title.children: 'It's like an ocean': Space-time is warped by a background of gravitational waves, and astronomers may have detected it for the first time

image.altText: A low cloud hanging over Uluru in June 2023

items.synopsis: It's a forecast that sounds unbelievable, but the Bureau of Meteorology says there's "the most outside chance" of snowfall on the cards for central Australia this weekend.

title.children: Snow in the NT this weekend? It's not impossible. Here's what it would take

image.altText: marine creature living in shell eats fish

items.synopsis: Deadly cone snails reared from eggs in a laboratory aquarium uncover a potential treasure trove of new venoms for drug development.

title.children: Deadly marine creature could hold the secret to development of new drugs

image.altText: Celine Cremer smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Tasmania Police searching for missing Belgian tourist Celine Cremer say they have received expert medical advice the weather conditions she is lost in for at least nine days are "not survivable".

title.children: 'Not survivable': Growing concerns for Belgian tourist Celine Cremer as Tasmanian weather deteriorates

image.altText: Shiree smiles, looking at a sunset over the bush, wearing a hat.

items.synopsis: Shiree spent hours in the freezing bush of Namadgi National Park, waiting for help after injuring her ankle. Now she's among those advocating for good preparation before heading out for a bushwalk.

title.children: Shiree's run ended with a dislocated ankle and an 11-hour wait in the snow for rescue

image.altText: A man in a cowboy hat leans down and fixes an engine

items.synopsis: Known for his "cheeky smile" and "quick wit", 32-year-old Tom Grey died in a plane crash last year that was "not considered survivable" by Australian Transport and Safety Bureau investigators.

title.children: Bird strike caused Chinchilla plane crash that killed 'lovable' pilot, safety bureau finds

image.altText: The city skyline, with boats on the water in the foreground.

items.synopsis: For more than half a century, the Mobil oil refinery was at the heart of Melbourne's industrial west. But since its closure two years ago, vastly different hopes for the site's future have emerged.

title.children: After years of use as an oil refinery, residents hope this patch of land can be repurposed. But scientists aren't sure

image.altText: Taylor Swift smiling while holding an armful of awards.

items.synopsis: The maths are simple. Most Taylor Swift fans wanting tickets to her Australian shows will miss out, writes Paul Crosby.

title.children: Got Bad Blood because you couldn't get a T-Swift ticket? Understanding the maths behind it may help

image.altText: King Charles smiles and looks to the left.

items.synopsis: The annual report into royals' taxpayer-funded spending reveals the King has requested thermostats in royal homes be turned down to 19 degrees Celsius, and details how much was sent on the Queen's funeral.

title.children: Inflation hits royal finances as King Charles turns down heating to save emissions

image.altText: A woman sings on stage during a performance

items.synopsis: With the women's World Cup fast approaching, Mallrat and BENEE have unveiled the official anthem of the tournament, Do It Again.

title.children: 'Wake up, this is the start of it': Women's World Cup anthem revealed

image.altText: Steve Smith hits a straight drive back between the legs of a reaching Josh Tongue

items.synopsis: The stage could not have been more perfectly set for England to back up its post-Edgbaston confidence on day one at Lord's, but the hosts came out flat and the Australians took full advantage, writes Dean Bilton.

title.children: Bazball bluster turns to Lord's lethargy as England tackles day one with a lack of energy

image.altText: A cricket bowler kicks the turf in frustration.

items.synopsis: Kevin Pietersen takes aim at England after the team came onto the field late and conversed with the Australian batters during a lacklustre start to the Lord's Test.

title.children: 'Are you absolutely joking?': Ashes champ hits out at attitude of England after lacklustre Lord's start

image.altText: A sign for the Doomadgee Hospital.

items.synopsis: Police and the health service are investigating after the baby boy's death in Doomadgee yesterday. A community leader is urging residents to stay "calm and rational".

title.children: Five-month-old's sudden death in remote hospital under investigation

image.altText: Pedestrians

items.synopsis: Retail turnover rose in May, while job vacancies have declined 2 per cent, and the ASX has slipped into negative territory.

title.children: Retail turnover rises again, job vacancies decline, ASX slips into negative territory

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Law firm Phi Finney McDonald has today commenced a shareholder class action in the Supreme Court of Victoria against Medibank on behalf of shareholders, in relation to the company’s recent data breach. From its press release just now: From market close on 19 October 2022 when Medibank went into a trading halt, to 26 October 2022 when the suspension was lifted, Medibank’s share price dropped more than 18 per cent after details of the breach were released. Phi Finney McDonald’s class action alleges that Medibank engaged in misleading and deceptive conduct and breached its continuous disclosure obligations in relation to the adequacy of its privacy and information security protections. The class action seeks compensation for shareholders that suffered losses as a result of Medibank’s alleged disclosure failures. It is separate to the privacy litigation brought by Medibank customers whose personal and health information was breached. Cameron Myers, Principal Lawyer at Phi Finney McDonald, said that following a preliminary investigation the firm considers there are grounds for legal action against the health insurer. “Medibank’s customers and shareholders quite rightly expected the company, as one of Australia’s largest private health insurers, to take adequate steps to protect the incredibly sensitive information that it held. Indeed, Medibank fostered this belief by informing the market that it had appropriate protections in place.” “The market was clearly concerned about the distress and related impact on customers whose data had been accessed, and what that meant for company costs and revenue. Based on our preliminary investigations, we believe that Medibank shareholders are entitled to be compensated for losses suffered from the erosion of trust and confidence in Medibank once the true state of affairs was acutely exposed.”
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Medibank to face shareholder class action over data breach

children.content: Law firm
Phi Finney McDonald
has today commenced a shareholder class action in the
Supreme Court of Victoria
against Medibank on behalf of shareholders, in relation to the company’s recent data breach.
From its press release just now:

From market close on 19 October 2022 when Medibank went into a trading halt, to 26 October 2022 when the suspension was lifted, Medibank’s share price dropped more than 18 per cent after details of the breach were released.

Phi Finney McDonald’s class action alleges that Medibank engaged in misleading and deceptive conduct and breached its continuous disclosure obligations in relation to the adequacy of its privacy and information security protections.

The class action seeks compensation for shareholders that suffered losses as a result of Medibank’s alleged disclosure failures. It is separate to the privacy litigation brought by Medibank customers whose personal and health information was breached.
Cameron Myers, Principal Lawyer at Phi Finney McDonald, said that following a preliminary investigation the firm considers there are grounds for legal action against the health insurer.

“Medibank’s customers and shareholders quite rightly expected the company, as one of Australia’s largest private health insurers, to take adequate steps to protect the incredibly sensitive information that it held. Indeed, Medibank fostered this belief by informing the market that it had appropriate protections in place.”

“The market was clearly concerned about the distress and related impact on customers whose data had been accessed, and what that meant for company costs and revenue. Based on our preliminary investigations, we believe that Medibank shareholders are entitled to be compensated for losses suffered from the erosion of trust and confidence in Medibank once the true state of affairs was acutely exposed.”

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has issued 38 interim stop orders that relate to 67 pet insurance products issued by the The Hollard Insurance Company and PetSure. The stop orders relate to pet insurance products issued by the insurance via brands including: Woolworths RSPCA Petbarn Guide Dogs Medibank Bpua HCF The interim orders prohibit the insurers from engaging in retail product distribution in respect of the products for new customers. The orders are valid for 21 days unless revoked earlier. ASIC made the interim orders to protect consumers from acquiring pet insurance products that may not be consistent with their objectives, financial situation or needs. ASIC has issued the stop orders because of deficiencies in the target market determinations (TMD) for the products. The regulator says it's considering more stop orders for other insurance products. ASIC says it was concerned that the insurers did not appear to properly consider whether the key terms, features and attributes of the products would be consistent with the objectives, financial situation and needs of consumers in the target market. In particular, in defining the target market, it appears that the insurers did not properly consider the requirement for consumers to pay for veterinary expenses in full and upfront before receiving a partial reimbursement under a claim. ASIC says it expects the insurers to consider the concerns raised regarding the TMDs and take immediate steps to ensure compliance. It will consider making a final order if the concerns are not addressed in a timely manner. The insurers will have an opportunity to make submissions before a decision is made about any final stop orders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regulator issues 38 stop orders for pet insurance products

children.content: The Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) has issued 38 interim stop orders that relate to 67 pet insurance products issued by the The Hollard Insurance Company and PetSure.
The stop orders relate to pet insurance products issued by the insurance via brands including:
Woolworths
RSPCA
Petbarn
Guide Dogs
Medibank
Bpua
HCF
The interim orders prohibit the insurers from engaging in retail product distribution in respect of the products for new customers. The orders are valid for 21 days unless revoked earlier.
ASIC made the interim orders to protect consumers from acquiring pet insurance products that may not be consistent with their objectives, financial situation or needs
ASIC has issued the stop orders because of deficiencies in the target market determinations (TMD) for the products.
The regulator says it's considering more stop orders for other insurance products.

ASIC says it was concerned that the insurers did not appear to properly consider whether the key terms, features and attributes of the products would be consistent with the objectives, financial situation and needs of consumers in the target market. In particular, in defining the target market, it appears that the insurers did not properly consider the requirement for consumers to pay for veterinary expenses in full and upfront before receiving a partial reimbursement under a claim.
ASIC says it expects the insurers to consider the concerns raised regarding the TMDs and take immediate steps to ensure compliance.

It will consider making a final order if the concerns are not addressed in a timely manner. The insurers will have an opportunity to make submissions before a decision is made about any final stop orders.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Bureau of Statistics data show retail turnover rose 0.7 per cent in May 2023, following a flat result in April and a 0.4 per cent rise in March. ABS officials say the slight rise in retail turnover reflected the fact that consumers were taking advantage of larger-than-usual promotional activity and sales events for May.. So, despite the inflationary crisis, retail businesses were doing what they could to boost sales and consumers were responding. An early start to some end of financial year sales events boosted turnover along with Mother’s Day and the ‘Click Frenzy Mayhem’ sales event. Ben Dorber, ABS head of retail statistics, said: "Just as we saw during the November Black Friday sales last year, consumers appeared to take extra advantage of discounting during large sales events in May in response to cost-of-living pressures."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian retail turnover rose 0.7 per cent in May

children.content: Bureau of Statistics data show retail turnover rose 0.7 per cent in May 2023, following a flat result in April and a 0.4 per cent rise in March.
ABS officials say the slight rise in retail turnover reflected the fact that consumers were taking advantage of larger-than-usual promotional activity and sales events for May..
So, despite the inflationary crisis, retail businesses were doing what they could to boost sales and consumers were responding.
An early start to some end of financial year sales events boosted turnover along with Mother’s Day and the ‘Click Frenzy Mayhem’ sales event.

Ben Dorber, ABS head of retail statistics, said: "Just as we saw during the November Black Friday sales last year, consumers appeared to take extra advantage of discounting during large sales events in May in response to cost-of-living pressures."

image.altText: Taylor Swift sings into a microphone while performing on stage.

items.synopsis: American pop star Taylor Swift adds two new shows to her 2024 Australian tour, which organisers say will be the final dates to be announced.

title.children: Taylor Swift adds two 'final' shows to Australian tour after 'historically unprecedented demand'

image.altText: Artist impression of a violent merger between two stars

items.synopsis: Around 520 light years away lies a Jupiter-sized planet that should have been destroyed.  So how did it survive?  It could have been like Tatooine from Star Wars.

title.children: 'The most fun part of science': Scientists discover a planet that should not exist
